comment.content: One reason is security, so that sensitive information such as usernames or passwords cannot be changed.
Another reason is synchronization or concurrency---being immutable also means that String is thread safe which resolves issues with synchronization.
Another reason is caching. The compiler recognizes that only one string object is needed, when we have two objects with the same value.

comment.content: Use a stack when you want to reverse the order of items that you added, and use a queue when you want to maintain the order of items that you added

comment.content: CS 132 is essentially linear algebra with a bit of coding in python. It would be a good idea to brush up on Python concepts and expect a lot of math.

About the same amount of material as 131, but the material is much easier to comprehend. There are around 15 problems per problem set, with most of it being written and a small portion being coding/computational. Expect to spend at least 5 hours/week on problem sets.
The first few weeks of 132 cover parts of 131.

comment.content: 210 is definitely moderately difficult, but there is a lot of time given to understand the material.
When I took it, there were 5 problem sets with sufficient time in between to complete them. Definitely utilize office hours for help on the homework.
210 is divided into two parts. The first half focuses on Linux/Unix. The second half delves deep into the von Neumann architecture, and towards the end, the course touches on C programming.

comment.content: Malloc stands for memory allocation and is a C library function that allocates memory from the heap. Malloc returns a pointer that is used to access the memory that was allocated.
The general syntax of 'malloc' is ptr = (cast-type*) malloc(byte-size).
An example to add on would be 'ptr = (int*) malloc(100 * sizeof(int));', which allocates 400 bytes of memory.

comment.content: The key takeaway from the Monty Hall problem is that decisions are heavily influenced by previous decisions.

In an example with 3 doors, we have a 2/3 of selecting a wrong door and 1/3 chance of choosing the right door. There is a 2/3 chance that we pick the wrong door initially then switch to the right door, but only a 1/3 chance of picking the right door initially then switching to a wrong door.

CS330 wasn't that bad.

CS 330 goes in depth with data structures and algorithms, such as graphs, BFS, DFS, Djikstra's, greedy, dynamic programming, etc... There will be coding and written parts on the HW that will be extremely time-consuming. You will want to put the most effort into this class.

posts.title: Clarifying time complexity of this algorithm

comment.content: Use BFS to find shortest path
BFS searches adjacent nodes, so it will find the shortest path quicker, since we will run out of nodes to add to the queue sooner for that path.
DFS is better for decision based problems and is quicker than BFS, since it doesn't search all neighbors.

posts.content: When should I use BFS over DFS in graph problems?
posts.title: BFS vs DFS

comment.content: Simply put, Dijkstra's algorithm allows us to find the shortest path between any two vertices of a graph.
